tossups.question: Three weeks after her cat Frederick dies, a woman with this job gets accused of drunkenly pooping in her friend’s handbag at a shoe store. Another TV character with this job raises her drug-addicted daughter Becky with Bobby Briggs after breaking up with her abusive husband Leo (*) Johnson. In the first episode of one TV series, a woman jilts Barry at the altar and is hired for this job by a peroxide-blonde manager with a crush on her, while another character with this job agrees to see the musical “The Nightman Cometh” to get rid of Charlie Kelly. For 10 points, name this job performed by Rachel Green at Central Perk, serving customers at tables.

Many of the native people of this island group practise a form of monotheistic animism that worships Paluga, with Paluga’s residence being Saddle Peak, the highest point of this group. The southern extent of these islands is defined by the Ten Degree Channel, and this island group is home to one of the world’s last uncontacted tribes, the (*) Sentinelese. These islands continue the Arakan Yoma and their largest settlement and capital is Port Blair. For 10 points, name this island group in the Bay of Bengal, forming a territory of India with the Nicobar Islands.

When offered a chance to leave the country, this character laments “I am chained to my old life”, and had earlier claimed to have “no certain roof but the coffin lid”. A boy who claims to be called Morris Bolter overhears this character talking to (*) Rose Maylie on London Bridge, and this character later dies clutching Rose’s handkerchief. This character’s former lover returns to London after having visions of her ghost, only to accidentally hang himself. For 10 points, name this implied prostitute who informs on Fagin and gets murdered by her lover Bill Sikes in Oliver Twist.

In a letter to Johann Lavater, this thinker condemned the “religion of ingratiation” based on flattering God. This thinker warned that “freedom in thinking signifies the subjection of reason to no laws except those which it gives itself” in the essay What is Orientation in Thinking?, his (*) intervention in the Mendelssohn- Jacobi feud. This author of Religion within the Bounds of Reason Alone called the title idea of another essay “man’s emergence from his self-imposed tutelage.” For 10 points, name this thinker, who declared “Sapere aude!” [sa-PEH-ray OW-day] in “What is Enlightenment?”.

In one story by this author, Mary is told by Stephen that her husband is alive and Margaret’s is dead, though Margaret is told the opposite by Goodman Parker. In another story by this author, one character opines that if the title object were to blow away, Reverend Hooper (*) would be fearful of a dead woman’s glance. In a novel by this author, Pearl is ostracised on the basis that her mother wears the title accessory, a symbol of her affair with Arthur Dimmesdale. For 10 points, name this author of The Wives of the Dead, The Minister’s Black Veil, and The Scarlet Letter.

Thomas Madox published a history of this institution in 1711. Much of our knowledge of this institution’s operations in medieval times derives from Richard FitzNeal’s ‘Dialogue concerning [it]’. The Pipe Rolls contain 700 years’ worth of this institution’s records, and Charles II decreed a disastrous “Stop” of this institution in 1672. (*) Its head annually gives a “Mansion House Speech,” and this institution’s name derives from the resemblance of this institution’s tax payment tables to a chessboard. For 10 points, name this institution, whose current Chancellor is Philip Hammond.

In one poem, the narrator insists that he is not wooing one of these figures, since he knows that if he did so, they would not come. In another poem by the same author, one of these figures is asked to pluck a smile from someone, and place it in an urn inscribed “Subrisio saltat”. (*) The second poem in one collection begins by noting that every one of these beings “is terror”; that collection opens by asking “who, if I cried out, would hear me among the” orders of these beings. Featured often in Rilke’s Duino Elegies, for 10 points, name these supernatural Christian beings.

The largest examples of these events, such as at Cap Blanc and Storegga, are thought to occur due to the interaction between diatomaceous layers and overlying clays. The largest-known subaerial example of these events occurred at Heart Mountain about 48 million years ago, and these events often occur when saturation-induced pore (*) water pressures reduce normal stress below a critical value, fatally destabilising a layer of sediment or rock. For 10 points, name these events, where slope failure leads to the sudden downhill movement of large volumes of material.
tossups.answer: landslides [accept landslip, prompt on mass wasting, antiprompt on more specific kinds of slide] <SC>

tossups.question: A coup in this city failed when the assassin sent to kill its founder bowed out of habit then gave him a piggyback ride to safety. A temple in this city hosts what is called 'the world's largest book', a set of 729 slabs relaying the Tripitaka. Much of the previous capital of Amarapura was (*) moved upriver to build this last capital of the Konbaung dynasty, and this city’s capture by the British forced the abdication of Thibaw Min. In World War II, the royal palace here was burned down by Allied and Japanese bombing. For 10 points, name this city, the last royal capital of Burma.

In one film set in this city, a man uses a fire extinguisher to crush the skull of ‘The Tapeworm’. Another film in this city opens with a shot of a Molotov cocktail being thrown at an image of the Earth; that black and white film set in this city depicts 20 hours in the life of three friends after Abdel gets (*) beaten up by police amid a violent suburban riot. In another film set in this city, returning a box of childhood memorabilia to the former owner of her apartment prompts a waitress to do good deeds for those around her, and fall for oddball Nino. For 10 points, name this city, the setting of Irreversible, La Haine, and Amélie.

People performing a Shinto form of this practice often have a paper wand called an ōnusa waved over them. Hindus perform this action on murtis in the Abhisheka ritual, and priests perform this action while uttering Da, Domine, virtutem manibus as part of Vesting Prayers. The (*) tevilah form of this practice may take place in a mikveh. The tayammum type of this action is done instead of wuḍū when only sand or dust is available. For 10 points, give this ritualistic practice required before entering a mosque and often done before prayer.
tossups.answer: Washing oneself [and equivalents like bathing; accept ritual purification in general until “Da, domine” and prompt thereafter; accept on any answer that gives a specific body part as the object of the verb, such as washing hands] <LC>

tossups.question: James Northcote painted the marriage of one of these people to Anne de Mowbray. Dominic Mancini described one of these people as having “scholarly attainments far beyond his age”. Evidence of hypodontia found by John Ashdown-Hill may disprove claims that workmen rebuilding a stairway in 1674 found (*) the remains of these people. A College of Arms manuscript suggests these people were killed “by the vise” of Henry Stafford, while Thomas More claimed that Sir James Tyrell confessed to the crime. For 10 points, name these two boys, whose alleged murder is often attributed to Richard III.
tossups.answer: Princes in the Tower [accept Edward V and Richard of Shrewsbury, Duke of York; accept any answer referring to the two princes possibly murdered by Richard III in the Tower of London] <LC>

tossups.question: One person with this name took the armillary sphere as their personal heraldic badge and later gave their name to the style of architecture made famous by the Tower of Bélem. Another person with this name was defeated at Myriokephalon by the Seljuks, whilst another was the target of (*) Operation Nifty Package, which saw rock music played loudly outside an embassy of the Vatican. A character with this name insisted that a rat was a Siberian Hamster. For 10 points, give this name, most popularly associated with a waiter from Barcelona in Fawlty Towers.

A 1961 paper showed that a restricted version of this system has unbounded oscillations, and is named for Sitnikov. This system is described by a slowly-converging series solution in T to the one-third power, as proven by Karl Sundman. Joseph-Louis (*) Lagrange first described the location of the points L4 and L5 in an essay on this system. Henri Poincaré proved that no general analytic solution exists for this system, of which the H2+ ion is a quantum version. For 10 points, name this mechanical system exemplified by the Earth, Moon and Sun.
tossups.answer: three-body problem/system (accept N-body problem/system, including any specific values of N other than 1 or 2; accept equivalent descriptions) <JK>

tossups.question: A 2005 World Bank investigation revealed that this company had been unethical in its attempt to privatize water in Delhi. This company sponsors the Dutch national football team and supports the Old Vic Theatre. In 2015, this company ended its 32-year partnership with (*) Tesco due to its hand in the supermarket overstating its profits. This company’s employees include Tim Cullinan and Martha Ruiz, the people who were responsible for La La Land being wrongly awarded the Oscar for Best Picture. For 10 points, name this Big Four firm, formed from a merger involving Pricewaterhouse.

In one work, this figure is killed by a man whose mother this figure contrived to have burnt; that man had just received a sword from an impersonator of Lile [pronounced like “Lily”] of Avelion. In another work, this child of Dyonas traps another character in the Forest of Broceliande. A character (*) identified as this figure is decapitated by Balin the Savage, and this figure raises the knights Lionel, Bors, and Lancelot. Other names for this figure include Vivian and Nimue. For 10 points, name this figure from Arthurian legend, who presented Arthur with Excalibur.
tossups.answer: the Lady of the Lake [prompt on strange women lying on their backs in ponds, distributing swords and such; also accept any of a bewildering variety of alternate names like Morgue, Evienne, Ninianne, or Nyneve; accept Vivian or Nimue until mentioned and prompt thereafter] <CB>

tossups.question: This man supposedly read Critique of Pure Reason to calm his nerves before sending an explosives- packed train at Okiep’s defenses. This coiner of the term “holism” wrote the first draft of the preamble to the UN Charter. With Louis Botha, this man suppressed the Maritz Revolt and founded the (*) Het Volk Party. This man resigned from De Beers after the Jameson Raid and led the invasion of German South West Africa in World War I. For 10 points, name this second Prime Minister of South Africa, who held the position from 1919 to 1924 and during World War II.

Aptitude for this action correlates with scores of Rapid Automatised Naming tests, supporting the double-deficit hypothesis. Louis Javal argued that “saccades” and “fixations” characterise muscle movements involved in this action. Marshall and Newcombe described a “surface” condition that impairs this action when (*) grapheme correspondences are irregular; that condition also has a “deep” form that causes semantic errors when this action is being done aloud. For 10 points, name this process taught using phonics, which is impaired by dyslexia.

A broken harpsichord threatened to disrupt the premiere of this piece at the Nikolaikirche in Leipzig. In this piece’s introduction, two oboes play dissonant minor 2nds over continuous semiquavers in the strings, after which the choir enters with the words (*) “Herr, Herr, Herr”. This piece’s composer reused its chorale “O Mensch, bewein dein Sünde Groß” for a later work in the same genre. A mezzo-soprano sings “Es ist vollbracht” at this work’s climax, the moment of crucifixion. For 10 points, name this Holy Week oratorio by J. S. Bach, written three years before the St Matthew Passion.
tossups.answer: St John Passion [accept Passio secundum Joannem or BWV 245] <Tom>

tossups.question: David Liu used these agents to speed up the optimisation of protein design through continuous evolution.  In a common technique for screening many protein-protein interactions, proteins of interest are expressed as fusion constructs with these pathogens’ pIII (*) [P-THREE] coat protein so that they are then displayed on the agent surface. Phosphorus-32 was incorporated into the genome of these pathogens to prove that DNA is genetic material in the Hershey-Chase experiment. Lambda and T4 are types of, for 10 points, which viruses that infect bacteria?
tossups.answer: bacteriophages (prompt on phages, accept specific types like lambda phage or M13 phage or T4 phage) <EM>

tossups.question: This molecule can undergo a cycloaddition with alpha-terpinene to form ascaridole. Methylene blue and Rose Bengal are commonly used reagents to form an especially reactive form of this molecule with term symbol 1Δg [ONE-DELTA-G]. Phenol and acetone are the products of the reaction between this molecule and (*) cumene. Carbon monoxide has a much greater affinity than this molecule for haemoglobin. Relighting a glowing splint is a test for the presence of, for 10 points, what diatomic gas that makes up around 20% of the atmosphere?
tossups.answer: dioxygen (accept O2, do not prompt or accept on “Ozone”) <EM>

tossups.question: A work titled for this man was partly funded by a lawsuit enforcing an annual alms this man instituted for a feast on St Thomas’ Day. That work highlights an Augustinian friar by framing the friar’s face with two torches. An angel carries a wispy figure believed to represent this man’s soul to the (*) upper “heavenly” half of a painting in which the artist’s son points to this man in ornate armor as Saint Stephen and Saint Augustine lay him to rest. For 10 points, name this Toledo nobleman whose miracle ‘burial’ is the subject of a work by El Greco.
tossups.answer: The Count of Orgaz [or Don Gonzalo Ruiz de Toledo] <JK>

tossups.question: John of Blanot’s Book of Homages emphasized this ruler’s judicial authority, bolstered by reformers like Odo of Rigaud and Matthew of Vendôme. The Treaty of Meaux betrothed Joan of Toulouse to a brother of this object of the first Shepherds’ Crusade, and his mother Blanche of Castile served as his regent. (*) His brother Charles led the Angevin conquest of Sicily and helped this ruler conquer Damietta, but at Fariskur was captured alongside this ruler by the Ayyubids. For 10 points name this leader of the Seventh and Eighth Crusades, the only King of France to be canonised.
tossups.answer: Louis IX [or St Louis; prompt on partial answer] (Charles of Anjou is not the brother married off by the Treaty of Meaux; that would be middle child Alphonse, Count of Toulouse ) <Tom>

tossups.question: In a short story by this author, Mina argues with her blind grandmother about missing church whilst crafting artificial roses. The title character of a novella by this author considers selling a rooster he’d been training to cockfight after failing to receive his (*) pension. In another work by this author, a photographer’s suicide using gold cyanide is deduced when Dr. Juvenal Urbino smells bitter almonds, and in that novel, Florentino Ariza waits 53 years to be reunited with his teenage sweetheart. For 10 points, name this author of No One Writes to the Colonel and Love in the Time of Cholera.
tossups.answer: Gabriel García Márquez [prompt on Marquez] <Tom> Bonuses:

bonuses.leadin: In this story, Ed’s teeth stick out like fangs after drinking rat poison, and he bungles killing himself again when he threatens two people who live “like fugitives”. For 10 points each:
answers: “What We Talk About When We Talk About Love”
cardiologist [accept heart surgeon, prompt on less specific medical professions] <LC>
parts: Name this short story, in which four friends in Albuquerque sit around a table drinking gin. Somehow they come onto the topic of the title concept, which may or may not be an absolute.
This author of “What We Talk About When We Talk About Love” was nominated for the National Book Award and the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction for his third major-press collection, Cathedral.

In the story, Mel McGinnis holds this specific profession, which sometimes “gives him the right”. After getting his words muddled, he elaborates that “I’m just a mechanic. I go in and I fuck around and I fix things.”

bonuses.leadin: This substance, which is produced by the choroid plexuses, is sometimes described as ‘gin clear’. For 10 points each:
answers: Foramen of Magendie [accept median aperture or medial aperture] <DJL>
parts: Name this substance that provides mechanical and immunological protection to the brain. A sample can be obtained via a lumbar puncture.
CSF fills these interconnected cavities in the brain, which are continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord. They share their name with a type of chamber in the heart.
CSF drains from the fourth ventricle to the cisterna magna of the subarachnoid space via this opening, often named for a French physiologist.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about lovers of the classical gods, for 10 points each:
parts: This goddess’s role as another deity’s lover is decidedly reluctant, but she ate several pomegranate seeds so she has to stay half the year in the Underworld. She even had to share her own lover, Adonis, with Aphrodite.
This lover of Eos [EY-os] supposedly aged into a cicada since Eos forgot to ask for eternal youth along with the immortality bestowed on this Trojan prince.

Apollo was so furious when this lover of his fell in love with the mortal Ischys that he forgot that having Artemis kill her would also kill this woman’s unborn son Asclepios, though Hermes managed to save him.

bonuses.leadin: It is time for you to search your Inner Eye and unfog the clouds of the future by naming some techniques of divination. For 10 points each:
answers: palmistry or chiromancy [accept any description involving palms]
Tesseography [accept any description involving tea leaves, coffee grounds, or wine sediments] <LC>
parts: In this divining technique, it was hoped that a depicted figure’s association with astrology would help predictions. It became popular in Europe in the 14th century and typically uses a set of 52 images.
A school of this technique was established in London by William John Warner. Readings can be taken by tracing lines and mounts, as well as identifying dermatoglyphics.
The first use of this technique is traced back to 229 BC when a princess rejected astrological predictions in favour of interpreting the colours of sedimentary symbols.

bonuses.leadin: Who needs bar lines anyway? Answer some questions on avant-garde composers who have eschewed traditional rhythm and meter, for 10 points each:
parts: This Ukrainian-Canadian pianist is known for pioneering “continuous music” on works such as his album KMH. He holds several speed-playing world records, including sustaining an average of 14 notes per second for a full hour.

This other piano composer used free time for his five hour unfinished magnum opus, The Well-Tuned Piano. This minimalist also founded the Theatre of Eternal Music, whose members included Terry Riley and John Cale.
This Parisian composer was amongst the first in the Western tradition to avoid using bar-lines or time signatures, in works such as his Gnossiennes and Gymnopédies.

bonuses.leadin: In 1905, J.W. Salmond argued that the ghosts of these legal instruments “still haunt the precincts” of British law, and American judicial review heavily involves ones of “mandamus” and “certiorari.” For 10 points each:
answers: Lord Woolf [or Harry Kenneth Woolf; Baron Woolf] <ADG>
parts: Name these written orders from an administrative or judicial body, which dominated the procedure of English common law until the abolition of forms of action in the 1830s.

Responsibility for issuing writs originally lay with this English Officer of State, although that power was curtailed by the Provisions of Oxford. This office was amalgamated with Secretary of State for Justice in 2007.

The wide-ranging 1998 legal reforms named for this Master of the Rolls renamed many prerogative writs and created the modern British Civil Procedure Rules. He also led the enquiry into the 1990 Strangeways prison riot.

bonuses.leadin: This artist depicted a desperate man on his knees in the Muda Tower preparing to eat his children in his sculpture Ugolino and his Sons. For 10 points each:
answers: The Laocoön Group / Laocoön and his Sons <JK>
parts: Name this French sculptor, who included that work alongside The Thinker and The Kiss in his ensemble The Gates of Hell.

Rodin’s version of Ugolino and his Sons may have been inspired by a sculpture of the same story by this other 19th-century French sculptor. In this man’s version, Ugolino is depicted seated, and gnawing at his fingers.

The composition of Carpeaux’s Ugolino and his Sons is itself inspired by this ancient sculpture, depicting a Trojan priest and his family. It was excavated near Rome in 1506 and is attributed to Athenodorus, Agesander, and Polydorus.

bonuses.leadin: The Arctic has a lot of island groups, some of which are becoming increasingly strategic as the ice melts. For 10 points each:
parts: This island group is nominally owned by Norway, but, according to the Spitsbergen Treaty of 1920, citizens of any signatory nation, including Russia and the USA, have access to the archipelago and its resources.

This settlement is the capital of Svalbard and its largest town. It is named after an American miner and its population is surprisingly multinational - 16% is non-Norwegian, including a substantial Thai minority.

One area where all the signatories of the Treaty agree on Svalbard’s use is science. As well as many glaciers and smaller ice caps, it contains this ice cap, the largest by area in Europe, making it of great interest to glaciology.

bonuses.leadin: Legendre? More like LEGEND-re. For 10 points each, name some things about the mathematical contributions of Adrien-Marie Legendre while the editorial team of this tournament does penance for that “joke”:
answers: Quadratic residue [prompt on partial answer, or attempted descriptions]
Convexity [accept words forms; prompt on concave upward early, but not just concave] <JK>
parts: Legendre’s name is perhaps most associated with a set of polynomials with this property, which means that the integral of any two distinct Legendre polynomials from -1 to 1 is zero, if one interprets the integral as an inner product.
The Legendre symbol is a multiplicative function, usually written [open bracket] a over p [close bracket], where p is an odd prime. It takes the value 1 if a is a non-zero one of these values mod p.

The Legendre transformation of a function will always have this property. Functions have this property if their second derivative is everywhere non-negative, and this property is sometimes called ‘concave upward’.

bonuses.leadin: These programs aimed at compulsory collectivisation of the peasantry as a solution to food shortages and rising prices in a “revolution from above,” and the White Sea Canal became a symbol of the first one. For 10 points each:
answers: Five-Year Plans for the Development of the National Economy of the Soviet Union [or Pyatiletki]
the New Economic Policy [or Novaya Ekonomicheskaya Politika]
Aleksei Grigoryevich Stakhanov [also accept the Stakhanovite Movement] <LC>
parts: This name is given to Joseph Stalin’s proposals for developing the Soviet economy. The first ran from 1928 to 1932 with the hope of promoting “Socialism in One Country,” but resulted in widespread, devastating famines.

Stalin devised the first Five-Year Plan to replace this program of limited free markets instituted by Lenin and championed by Nikolai Bukharin. It enacted the prodnalog agricultural tax and resulted in the Scissors Crisis.

During the second five-year plan, this man inspired a propaganda cult after allegedly mining 102 tons of coal in under 6 hours. His model and namesake “movement” was used to offer bonuses to exemplary workers.

bonuses.leadin: A manuscript of this author’s play The Mother-in-Law may contain one of the only remaining pieces of Ancient Roman music. For 10 points each:
answers: Terence [accept Publius Terentius Afer; prompt on partial]
parts: Name this Roman playwright, a freed slave who inspired Moliere’s A School for Husbands with his play Adelphoe. His other works include The Eunuch and The Self-Tormentors.

This play by Terence was the first of his to be performed. At the beginning of this play, Chremes revokes permission for Pamphilus to marry Glycerium, the title character, after the former acts up at a funeral.

This Renaissance writer first ventured into the theatre by adapting Terence’s Andria for the Florentine stage. His later plays include The Mandrake, though he is perhaps better known for political treatises like The Prince.

bonuses.leadin: In solid state physics, most important constructions are best visualised in momentum space rather than real space. For 10 points each:
answers: Laue’s condition [accept Bragg’s Law which may be demonstrated as functionally equivalent] <YY>
parts: Give this letter, commonly used to denote momentum space. It is also used as the symbol for Boltzmann's constant, as well as the SI unit of temperature.
The first one of these regions are defined as the Wigner-Seitz cell of the reciprocal lattice: the locus of points which are closest to a given reciprocal lattice point than any other.

This condition states that in elastic scattering, the incident and scattered momentum vectors differ by a reciprocal lattice vector. That is to say that the projection of the primitive vector onto the scattering vector must equal two pi times the relevant Miller index.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of this play angrily dissolves Parliament after refusing to pass a Bill for statutory regulation of the press. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this play by Mike Bartlett, which premiered at the Almeida Theatre in 2014. In this play, the Republican Jess convinces Harry to renounce his family name, and the Duchess of Cambridge plots her husband’s rise to power.

Mike Bartlett is also known for his adaptation of this play by Euripides, which inspired him to write the TV series Doctor Foster. This play’s title character kills her own children after her husband Jason marries Glauce.
Bartlett’s latest work is this play, inspired by The Cherry Orchard, in which Audrey yearns for a romanticised lost England whilst restoring her Oxfordshire childhood home.

bonuses.leadin: The critical technology behind this asset, the blockchain, was the brainchild of the pseudonymous “Satoshi Nakamoto”. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this asset. 50 Cent’s decision to accept this asset as payment for a 2014 album has recently led to him earning millions of dollars during an unprecedented “boom” in this digital commodity.

Bitcoin is the big daddy of cryptocurrency, but not all of its dealings are above board. It is often used in online black markets such as this one founded by Dread Pirate Roberts. Its third iteration folded in 2017.

If you missed out on the Bitcoin bonanza, you could invest in this blockchain platform created by Vitalik Buterin. It features smart contract functionality for decentralised applications, and is already in use by RBS.

bonuses.leadin: This work argues that the state cannot be defined by “enumerating its activities,” but only by the specific means that are available to it. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1919 essay, which goes on to describe the state as that which has “a monopoly on legitimate physical violence” within a territory.
‘Politics as a Vocation” is an essay by this German sociologist, who also wrote The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism.
In “Politics as a Vocation”, Weber argues that the practice of politics is difficult because politicians are prone to this quality, which makes them emotionally attached to their followers.

bonuses.leadin: These peoples’ sites of Issyk and Kul-Oba contained massive amounts of gold, some of which was decorated with motifs of animals fighting fantastic beasts in their distinctive “animal-style” art. For 10 points each:
answers: the Scythians [also accept the Sakae, Massagetae, Iskuzai, or Skolotai; also accept Samatians, Alans, or Ossetians even though there is significant debate over whether those later Iranic “Scythians” are the same Scythians as the earlier ones]
parts: Name these pointy hat-wearing horsemen, who popularized the composite bow and dominated the steppes north of the Black Sea. These targets of several Achaemenid campaigns left behind tombs called kurgans.

Much of our information on the Scythians, including details about their archaeologically-verified fondness for cannabis, comes from this rather unreliable Greek historian known as the “Father of History.”

This key Scythian archaeological site, a burial in the Altai mountains, produced such discoveries as mummies of a heavily-tattooed chief and the “Siberian Ice Maiden”, as well as what is likely the world’s oldest pile carpet.

bonuses.leadin: Locating those who are missing can be an exciting affair, and has cropped up as the crux of many a pop culture phenomenon. For 10 points each:
answers: Wally (accept Waldo, accept Where’s Wally? Or Where’s Waldo?)
Star Trek III: The Search For Spock [accept either underlined portion] <SC>
parts: One such person who always seems to need locating is this lanky bespectacled man with a penchant for red and white clothing, created by Martin Handford.
In an eponymous series of video games, locating where this international supervillain and head of V.I.L.E [vile] is in both space and time is a very important task for A.C.M.E [acme].
In this film, the crew of the USS Enterprise travel to the forbidden Genesis planet to locate the body of a dead crew member.

bonuses.leadin: Bombs, Bullets, and Business as Usual subtitled a 2011 documentary by Richard Weller about a particularly detonation-prone one of these places. For 10 points each:
answers: The Troubles [accept the Northern Ireland conflict]
parts: A man using the pseudonym “Roy Walsh” placed a device made from an egg timer and a VCR in a bathroom in one of these places, but the person he intended to assassinate happened to be up late writing a speech.
Provisional IRA member Patrick Magee targeted Margaret Thatcher in the Brighton Hotel Bombing during this conflict. It is typically said to have ended with the Good Friday Agreement of 1998.

Journalists covering the Troubles often stayed at this “Hardboard Hotel” on Great Victoria Street, Belfast, which has suffered 36 bomb attacks since it opened in 1971. It claims to be the “most bombed hotel in Europe.”

bonuses.leadin: In this novel, a drunk Ernest Hemingway seeks out the “bastard” who “insulted [his] cojones”. For 10 points each:
answers: Anthony Burgess [or John Anthony Burgess Wilson] <Theo>
parts: Name this novel which describes the efforts of aging writer Kenneth Toomey to help canonise Carlo Campanati. This novel’s opening line describes Kenneth in bed with his catamite on his 81st birthday.

Toomey is said to be based upon this British “first-rate writer of the second rank”, since this man was also homosexual and interested in colonial South-East Asia. This author created Charles Strickland, a fictionalised Gauguin.
Earthly Powers is a work of this British novelist and translator who wrote the Enderby Quartet. This author also created the language Nadsat for use in his novel A Clockwork Orange.

bonuses.leadin: Judith Butler argues that this concept is “performative” in a work named for this concept’s Trouble. For 10 points each:
answers: Posthumanism [also accept transhumanism and word forms; prompt on anything similar to futurism or antihumanism and word forms].
parts: Name this concept, hierarchical social structures of which are often called “patriarchy” in contemporary feminism, which seeks, among other things, to analyse and undermine the namesake “roles” of this thing.

N. Katherine Hayles, Rosi Braidotti, and the “cyborg feminist” Donna Haraway have incorporated feminism into this field, which attacks post-Enlightenment anthropocentrism. Other scholars in it focus on “the singularity.”

This pioneer of eco-feminism challenged humans’ “standpoint of mastery” and links it to patriarchal attitudes in Feminism and the Mastery of Nature. She partly credits those insights to nearly being eaten by a crocodile.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the Maccabees:
answers: Sukkot [or the Feast of the Booths; or the Feast of the Tabernacles] <HO>
parts: After the Maccabean revolt, Judas Maccabeus determined that every year the rededication of the Temple should be observed for eight days after a day of oil lasted that long, creating this Jewish festival of lights.

According to the Books of the Maccabees, this priest and father of Judas Maccabeus inspired and at first led the revolt after killing a Jew who had made a sacrifice to the pagan Gods and the Greek official enforcing it.
The “first Hanukkah” celebrated by the Maccabees was, according to 2 Maccabees, in fact a delayed observance of this festival, which heavily involves the hadass, aravah, lulav, and etrog.

bonuses.leadin: NMR spectroscopy of this nucleus is much less sensitive than proton NMR owing to its low abundance and small gyromagnetic ratio. For 10 points each:
answers: DEPT (or Distortionless enhancement by polarisation transfer)
parts: Name this commonly studied nucleus whose chemical shifts range from about 0 to 220 ppm.
This NMR method can be used to determine whether a given carbon atom is primary, secondary or tertiary. Depending on pulse angle, carbons bonded to different numbers of protons will become inverted.
This common solvent for NMR experiments will show up in carbon-13 NMR as a triple peak at 77 ppm.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about an assortment of easy pieces:
parts: The French princess Eugene Murat commissioned “Five Easy Pieces”, a set of piano duets by this composer. This composer wrote the Dumbarton Oaks concerto in his neoclassical phase.

“Six Easy Pieces” is the abridged version of a collection of lectures by this Caltech physicist. This physicist won the Nobel for his work on quantum electrodynamics and names diagrams used to model particle interactions.

This artist one-upped Feynman by presenting “Seven Easy Pieces” at the New York Guggenheim in 2005. Other major works by this “grandmother of performance art” have included “The Artist is Present” and “Rhythm Zero”.

bonuses.leadin: Historians like Paula Nuttall have proposed a meeting between this artist and Antonello da Messina as a key intersection between the Northern Renaissance and the Italian Renaissance. For 10 points each:
answers: Madonna and Child [also accept answers like Virgin and Child, Mary and Child, or Our Lady] <JK>
parts: Name this Bruges painter, said to be the first Northern painter to master linear perspective, whose works include Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints Francis and Jerome and Portrait of a Carthusian.
Petrus Christus’ predecessor in the Bruges school, and perhaps his teacher, was this Flemish painter who created the Ghent Altarpiece with his brother, Hubert.

Petrus Christus’ best-known depiction of this religious scene unusually takes place in the branches of a dry tree. Van Eyck’s paintings of this scene include ones named for Canon van der Paele and for Chancellor Rolin.
